name: Evil Speed Caster: Sorc 35 / Monk 3 / BG 2
author: UrbanHermit

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
The build is inspired by the Speed Caster by WhiZard:
The point of the build is that the Monk speed feat overrides the speedcap of +50% and let you stack speed from different spells (mass haste, expeditious retreat) so you can move with an insane speed. It takes 3 levels of monk to get the feat. (See the speed calculations in WhiZard's post)
WhiZard also uses one level of Paladin for the Divine grace feat to get a save boost from the high charisma. In my build I use 2 levels of BG for the Dark blessing feat with the same effect.

An important question is when to take the monk and BG levels. If you spread them out evenly, you will have skill dumps for optimum skill investment. If you build for lvl 40, it is best to take those classes late for the same reason.
If you level up your character in a normal way, playing the levels, you may want to get Monk 3 early so you can zoom around at high speed during leveling. The same goes for the save boost from BG. But then again if you multiclass a sorcerer too early you will lack the spellpower necessary for carefree levelling.
This character will not stand and fight like a tank in full armor with expertise on, it is supposed to RUN, so I have dropped Discipline and left Tumble at 15, just enough to avoid AOOs when running around.

The build can be tweaked like you suggest if you want an evil version of the Exalted Sorceress, with Tower & Full plate, Divine Shield, max Tumble, Discipline and Concentration, high saves and Evasion, and casting with Auto still spell. Then you get a sorcerer with high defence that can stand and fight and shrug off most attacks from lesser creatures.

The Evil Speed Caster is designed to move very fast. To be able to do that it has the Monk speed feat (Monk 3) that removes the +50% cap on speed and let you stack speed effects from sources like Monk speed, Expeditious retreat and Mass haste. The Monk speed feat does not work if you wear armor or shield of any kind. And AC is not a priority here. If you (despite your maneuverability) end up in a situation where you need AC, you may use your Epic warding.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
If I ever play a sorcerer again (and there really is zero chance of that happening in this lifetime), it would be this one.  Just sheer perfection of the synergies both for saves and nasty speed. Plus, all sorcerers should be evil!

One question, though... why Silent & Quicken? 

There are so few spells (IIRC, a total of 3) that can be silenced and assuming this toon is going to be spending quality time venturing while hasted... :-S

The only thing I can think of is possible AoOs that Quicken can avoid and/or perhaps just fishing for more meta slots to manage your casting better.  I wooda thunk focusing in an add'l school like Evocation would have had more net value, but then again, I like to prepare an ideal spell repertoire in advance of each encounter so have little experience managing a sorc's limited spell list.  Pretend I am an aspiring spontaneous caster and explain these two feat choices, please.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Thank you Hip for the kind words.

Silence and quicken are there for extra meta slots, one and four levels higher.
Extend is there for the 1 round per level buffs. Silence is primarily there for the list of spells that cannot be extended, which are quite a few.

The build has meta magical feats for two reasons. One is the improved effect meta-magic adds. The other is added slots.
And like you know this is the beauty of the sponaneous caster: Eg: If you need fire spells, you can cast Firebrand normally from all your level 5 slots, silenced from your level 6 slots, empowered from your level 7 slots, maximised from your level 8 slots and quickened from all your level 9 slots. You can virtually keep casting that spell all day long if you want.
And you can choose to do likewise with any other spell in your book without any preparation.

posts.author: HipRedux

Kalistez wrote:
Also can Expeditious Retreat stack with Mass Haste without having Monk speed in the equation, as in can i stack those 2 to get me by until I get monk 3 in epic ?

 
ER always stacks with Mass Haste for any toon capable of casting those spells either by spellbook or UMD (items).  But I would stick to Mick's leveling suggestion nonetheless.

One other caveat that may not be obvious to all aspiring speed demons out there... if your toon is equipping a permahaste item, you will need to unequip before applying the spell buffs, then either re-equip or equip an entirely different item with other properties. The permahaste property will have no effect on the synergy while the buffs are active.  Or you could re-equip permahaste as a prophylactic measure just in case the buffs are dispelled or expire.  At least that way you'll be guaranteed to get at least the 150% boost with +4AC regardless of possible negations.

@Mick:  Dunno if you've tested this or not so may not be able to confirm, but... does ER/MH stack with Barb speed?   Thinking of the potential of a Xanos-like clone build concept here.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
@ Noctem
This is primarily a caster build. I start out with pure Sorcerer to get the spellpower that makes levelling as caster possible without lagging behind on spell progression.
I prefer to add Monk and BG only when spellpower is up and running.
Monk and BG are only there to add extra speed and saves. This is not a spellsword and it is not some evil version of the "Exalted Sorceress". ( Of course I do have an "Infamous Sorcerer" build lurking somewhere in my folders.)

I do take Tumble, but only enough to avoid Attacks of opportunity when running past an enemy. I could have achieved that by taking Monk already at level 12, but IMO that is too early to slow down the spell progression.

And believe me, a pure Sorcerer is a very strong character, at least after level 8 or 10 or thereabout, so there is no reason at all to rush the multiclassing. The multiclassing even has a price when I take it this late. The 5 levels of other classes delay the point where the build becomes immune to the dispels. It also lowers spell penetration to such a degree that I often want to take the Spell penetration feat instead of Quicken spell.

@ Stag
I checked a screen dump. She was actually at level 24 when she killed Scar; Sorcerer 20/Monk 3/ BG 1.
As for Gnome, you are right. Gnome is in many ways a great race for spell casters with extra durability from the constitution bonus and a free Spell focus in Illusion, but here it would derail the necro focus, add an XP penallty and take away too many skill points.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Noctem wrote: did you solo this toon with just an eyestalk @Mick Dagger ?!? If so, what do you do about traps and locks? Do you just ignore them? Also, how do you manage to not die every 15 seconds with no meat shields?
These are general challenges for any Sorcerer and this one is not so different.
Early on the Sorcerer is a weak character with few spells and low defence. Up to level 8 -10 it is very hard to level a sorcerer without some kind of meat shield. I have tried it, and it involves a LOT of running. What I usually do at lower levels is to use a familiar with either high AC and HP, like the Pseudo dragon, or one of them with 5/+1 DR and regeneration, like the mephits and the Imp. But here I used the Eyeball. I also spawn the best summon I can afford, and I say so because the summoning line of spells is not my first choice once I get access to a new level of spells. Buying scrolls of summon animal is a good option when available. But after a while these summons just become too feeble.
At some point with this character I picked the spell Animate dead and buffed the skellie with Stone bones and what not. It served well as a tank for some levels. But that was more of a RP choice.
Before your enemies start to get +1 weapons, Ghostly Visage and 5/+1 defence works well.
At level 8 and 9 when you start to get level 4 spells, Stoneskin and Improved invisibility make you very durable. At level 10 Firebrand is your new "big stick", and you start to have enough slots and spells to choose from.  At this level range you can try going solo, at least for shorter periodes. Extended Haste or Expeditious retreat make you hard to catch.
When you feel confident with solo play, you can pick a utility Familiar like the pixie. It can take some punishment, but is not a tank. So the main reason for taking it is to have rogue skills available.
Not that you really need them. Magic missile is a good can opener. And a well placed Fireball can open many containers simultaneously. If you find a trap you cannot pass, you can always summon a Badger and have it run across it, and so on. And if you cannot detect the traps, you have spells that help you soak up damage. You always have the Knock and Find trap spells, but you don't have to learn them, just buy some scrolls if you don't like the methods above.
SpoilerIn Bracksworth you can buy some boots that give permanent speed improvement, like permanent Expeditious retrat. That makes running a lot easier. But you probably cannot afford them early on.
When you play the Aielund, you probably use the EMS hak. It changes several spells, and may be a bit unfamiliar if you have played casters elsewhere. Some of the changes I like, but others not. But it is definitely possible to play as a caster, also with EMS.
One thing I experienced was that when I buffed the main character, the Familiar got the same buffs automatically as a bonus.

Then, once I'm rich enough, I can always swap CF out for a more utilitarian spell at level-up, since Sorc's are rad that way. :)
SpoilerIf you are into it, it is possible to do the same thing with light gems. Some vendors sell them at about 10 gold. Another cheesy way of earning large amounts of gold is if you can craft electric traps and sell them to a fence.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Noctem wrote: Care to give this old n00b a rundown (or point me to a reliable thread if one already exists) to help me figure out what spells will give me the best bang for my buck, from a holistic standpoint not just a point-and-nuke philosophy.
Most posted spell suggestions list the choice of the poster when you have 20 sorcerer levels and full lvl 9 spell casting.
The pictures are from Aielund where you have EMS. That changes many spells and also influences what spells I prefer at different levels. I also picked some spells based on RP choices and left out some spells if item properties covered thir purpose.

At the end of the first act she had reached level 10 and knew the following spells:
Cantrips: All
Level 1: Mage armor, Shield, Negative energy ray, Protection from alignment, Ray of enfeeblement
Level 2: Ghostly visage, Resist elements, Bull's, Stone bones
Level 3: Fireball, Lightning bolt, Stinking cloud
Level 4: Stoneskin, Animate dead
Level 5: Firebrand
I had equipped an x-bow that let you cast unlimited Magic missile at caster level 5 and boots with permanent speed increase. I also used wands of fire, lightning and ice storm as back up. And items with find traps and knock to help pass difficult obstacles.

At level 20 she was Sorcerer 18/ Monk 2 and knew the following spells:
Cantrips: All
Level 1: As before
Level 2: Resist elements had been replaced by Eagle's
Level 3: Fireball, Lightning bolt, Flame arrow, Haste
Level 4: Stoneskin, Animate dead, Ice storm, Improved invisibility
Level 5: Firebrand, Cone of cold, Mestil's acid sheath, Energy buffer
Level 6: True seeing, Chain lightning, Greater dispelling
Level 7: Finger of death, Shadow shield, Delayed blast fireball
Level 8: Sunburst, Horrid wilting
Level 9: Wail of the banshee
She could still cast unlimited low level Magic missile and kept the boots that gives speed increase.

At level 27 she was Sorcerer 22/ Monk 3/ BG 2
Cantrips: As before
Level 1: Mage armor, Shield, Negative energy ray, Expeditious retreat, Identify
Level 2: Bull's, Cat's, Eagle's, Owls, Darkness
Level 3: Fireball, Lightning bolt, Flame arrow, Clarity
Level 4: Ice storm, Improved invisibility, Elemental shield, Fear
Level 5: As before
Level 6: True seeing, Chain lightning, IGMS
Level 7: Finger of death, Spell mantle, Shadow shield
Level 8: Sun burst, Horrid wilting, Premonition
Level 9: Wail of the banshee, Mordenkainens disjunction, Shape change

She now had items with perma haste and boosted her speed with extended ER.

Later she dropped Fireball and took Negative energy burst (to have a better way to do negative damage), she dropped Shapechange and took Bigby 9 and dropped Shadow shield for Banishment. She had good enough negative energy protection from items by then.
I never missed Time stop or Greater sanctuary, and even if Premonition became obsolete, I never felt the need to replace it with another level 8 spell.
She got Epic warding as scheduled in the build.
I tried to pick different types of attack spells to cover different immunities. Wail and Finger became my main attack spells, but many monsters were immune, so I needed other options.
You may wondeer why I took IGMS rather late. EMS nerfs it, so i prefered other options until it could fill a free slot withit and offer a different damage type

posts.author: Noctem
posts.content:
OK, back home and in front of the compie for a few minutes. Here's the rundown:
At Level 14

Cantrips: All
Level 1: Color Spray (still stuns trashmobs quite a bit!), Expeditious Retreat, Identify, Magic Missile, Shield
Level 2: Cat's Grace, Cloud of Bewilderment (marginally useful at this level, admittedly), Death Armor, Gedlee's Electric Loop (outdated, replacing next level), Web
Level 3: Flame Arrow, Negative Energy Burst, Scintillating Sphere, Slow
Level 4: Elemental Shield, Elemental Shield, Enervate (to nerf casters, which admittedly almost never show up), Evard's Black Tentacles
Level 5: Bigby's Interposing Hand, Cloudkill, Mestil's Acid Sheath
Level 6: Circle of Death, Tenser's Transformation
Level 7: Finger of Death

I also have the limitless Magic Missile xbow, Boots for Haste 1/day (plus a ring w/10 charges for backup!), and various direct damage/AOE spells through weapons, wands, and the like. 
The usual rotation looks something like this: Start the day with extended Expeditious Retreat then run around looking for things to kill. Once I spot something, I'll usually cast extended Shield and Cat's Grace for AC buff then attack with Neg Energy Burst > Web > EBT > Circle of Death > Scintillating Sphere and/or Gedlee's until they're all fried. If fighting a single attacker, or some groups, I'll go the reciprocal damage route by skipping Cat's and Shield, then popping Death Armor, Elemental Shield, Mestil's Acid Sheath, and Tenser's Transformation. 
But these routines vary, and every fight still feels fresh and different since I have gobs of spells to choose from. Once I level up I'm going to try your spell suggestions and see how that affects my playstyle.

posts.author: Noctem
posts.content:
I went back to an old save game (I try to remember to save before each level-up) but I didn't save before the last one, so I took a BIG step back to level 12 to reset those spell selections, just on a lark. It's a totally different game running around with a skellie chieftain and my familiar (I went back to the captive Pixie for rogue skills since I had been traveling with Ronan prior). It took a few minutes to get used to, but I have to say, I really like this iteration. Totally different playstyle, totally different vibe, and still a MONSTER. That skellie is surprisingly viable once I get him buffed up (and totally useless before I do). 
The only minor changes I made are that I kept Expeditious Retreat (I mean, I am an Evil Speed Caster, after all) over Ray of Enfeeblement at 1st level, Death Armor at 2nd, Scintillating Sphere over Fireball and Negative Energy Burst over Lightning Bolt at 3rd (I have 2 fireball  items anyway), and Elemental Shield over Ice Storm at 4th. That was a hard decision, but I'm addicted to the reciprocal damage plan, especially now that I have Stoneskin. All other spells are precisely the same as your outline. 

Can you put (under a spoiler) where to find those in Aielund? I don't think I've run across a pair of perma-hasted boots yet. I've just cleaned out the Assassin's guild and am ready to head south-southwest to put the smack down on some things living outside the city walls. 

Cheers!
-Noc

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: If I recall correctly, the Boots of Traveling are in Chapter 1 of Aielund, and they boost only your movement speed, but they do not give another attack nor boost your AC like true Haste.  I don't think it boosts other characters' speeds, unless they are wearing them, too, but that could have changed in more recent versions without me noticing.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
They are indeed in chapter 1. No need for a spoiler, as they are for sale at shop next to the Mayor's office in Bracksworth where you get your winter cloak(s). She sells non-metal gear and her husband ranged equipment. I'm fairly sure they boost party speed, but, as you say Empyre, they're not like true Haste.

I may be wrong here, but the House of Fashions in Fairloch might also sell them in chapter 2, along with an Improved version - though I've never been tempted to purchase the upgrade, as other haste items seem to start cropping up in chapter 2 as well, although they're still rare.

posts.content:

I think I'll stick with my Hasted Boots of Agility: Haste (10) 1/day, +2 AC (dodge). I don't mind the 1st level slot going to ER since there aren't a ton of 1st level spells that I cast on a regular basis, and I get to cast an obscene number of them with this CHA. 
:)
